title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to support the law enforcement components of a project to conserve the tiger in the Endau-Rompin landscape. The Recipient will do this by: (1) supporting joint patrols (once a month and up to five days in length), short patrols (up to twice a month and 2 to 5 days in length) and checkpoint operation at road accesses to the northern half of the Johor Endau Rompin landscape; (2) conducting land use ground-truthing and wildlife recce surveys in new forest conversions and habitat bottlenecks in parts of Mersing District; (3) highlighting use of these corridors by wildlife in a report to the Johor Wildlife Conservation Project Steering Committee; and (4) analyzing the current land-use at these vital bottle necks using GPS and GIS mapping.

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This project will strengthen protection of Bornean orangutans in and around these protected areas through more effective law enforcement. The Recipient will do this by: (1) facilitating discussions between Malaysian and Indonesian enforcement agencies on establishing a joint enforcement unit to address cross-border incursions by non-Malaysians; (2) training protected area staff in ranger patrol techniques and providing required patrol equipment; (3) increasing the number of anti-poaching patrols (from 12 to 18 each year); and (4) increasing the quality of anti-poaching efforts through the inclusion of WCS Malaysia staff as third party auditors.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Development of a Great Ape Health Unit in Sabah, Malaysia.

description.narrative: This project will promote the health of Sabahs gibbons and orangutans by creating a new Wildlife Health Monitoring and Surveillance Program that will work to minimize the risk of introducing infectious diseases to recipient populations from animals translocated from fragmented forests. It will also initiate research that will study the link between deforestation and disease in apes. The Recipient will do this by: (a) creating a Wildlife Health Unit within the Sabah Wildlife Department (SWD) including a veterinarian, a molecular biologist and four rangers as a subunit of the Wildlife Rescue Unit; (b) developing a Sabah Wildlife Health Monitoring and Surveillance Program to be led and implemented by the Wildlife Health Unit; (c) having the Wildlife Health Unit conduct ape health assessments, collect and analyze samples and store samples at the SWD Biobank; (d) processing clinical samples for infectious disease analysis; (e) training the Wildlife Health Unit to perform health assessments and clinical sampling for disease surveillance as part of rescue activities; (f) building much needed capacity by providing a vehicle for the Wildlife Health Unit to allow them to conduct disease surveillance and to respond to sick or injured animals across Sabah with optimal efficiency; (g) increasing laboratory capacity by training the molecular biologist to use PREDICT viral family PCR protocols; and (h) initiating a study on the effect deforestation has on ape health by analyzing the change in viral diversity along a deforestation gradient.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: African Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This project aims to improve the ability of the Royal Malaysian Customs officers to prevent illegal trade in ivory more effectively at selected ports in Malaysia. Funding will provide equipment and training (in English and Malay) to major ports on the west coast of peninsular Malaysia where large seizures of ivory occurred in the past year. Activities will include at least two trainings for Royal Malaysian Customs at ports including Port Klang in Selangor and Port of Pasir Gudang in Johor, and translating training and refernce material into the local Malay language. Topics covered will include policy restricting ivory trade, the latest information on illegal ivory trade routes and smuggling methods, and improved detection and interception of ivory shipments.

title.narrative: WCS/GoM Peninsular Malaysia Elephant Project: Year 8, assessment and reduction of humanelephant conflict (HEC) and capacity building in Endau-Rompin

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to help the Government of Malaysia develop a holistic elephant plan that will balance development and conservation, and help conserve wild elephant populations in Taman Negara, Endau Rompin Landscape (ERL), and elsewhere in Peninsular Malaysia. The specific project objectives include the following: 1) Enhance community-based human-elephant conflict mitigation work by providing training in safe and effective methods for driving elephants away from crops; 2) Improve the effectiveness of electric fences as elephant barriers to reduce elephant entries into human settlements and crop areas by implementing trial early warning system; 3) Protect elephant populations and their habitat from poachers and encroachment by conducting multi-stakeholder patrolling using the MIST or SMART patrol management systems; 4) Continue support for community-based mitigation schemes established in four Orang Asli villages.

title.narrative: Conservation of the tigers of the Endau-Rompin Landscape, Malaysia, through on the ground..law enforcement, 2013-2014

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring the tigers of the greater Endau-Rompin landscape up to the carrying capacity of the habitat. This will be done by maintaining anti-poaching enforcement activities in the Johor portion of the landscape including multi-agency anti-poaching patrols, mobile anti-poaching road blocks, anti-poaching vehicular patrols, and WCS-only foot and motorbike patrols (all guided by inputs from threat analyses, intelligence and reconnaissance trips); and carrying out surveillance camera-trapping for poachers in Johor.

description.narrative: Citizen Action for Tigers (CAT) - Supporting anti-poaching law enforcement efforts with citizen volunteers in the Sungai Yu Tiger Corridor and Taman Negara National Park, Malaysia

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to deter poaching activity at Sungai Yu Tiger Corridor and encroachment into Taman Negara; elicit reliable information on crimes against wildlife from the public to aid law enforcement; and cultivate wildlife stewardship among the Malaysian public. This will be done by (1) placing citizen volunteers at encroachment hotspots and on the Taman Negara border, especially on weekends and public holidays when enforcement staff are often not on duty; (2) having volunteers actively seek snares and traps and deactivate them while carrying out recreational activities or border maintenance work; and (3) having volunteers report suspicious activity to the Wildlife Crime Hotline.

description.narrative: Conservation of Orang-utans & Critical Habitats in Sabah, Malaysian Borneo (lmplementing the Orang-utan Sabah State Action Plan)

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to foster implementation of Sabahs Orangutan Action Plan. This will be done by: 1. developing information on trends in distribution, population densities and conservation status of the orangutan and other wildlife in several key areas in Sabah; 2. documenting the processes of ecological adaptation of the orangutan to degraded and fragmented habitat; 3. obtaining a better understanding of the patterns of use of oil palm plantation landscapes by orangutans; 4. formulating and achieving agreement with stakeholders on policies based on scientific knowledge for long-term conservation in Sabah; 5. achieving support and recognition for Sabahs efforts towards orangutan conservation; 5. reducing levels of degradation and fragmentation of orangutan habitats through improved land use management; 6. empowering indigenous communities in the management of local natural resources; 7. having model community initiatives lead to socio-economic and conservation gains; 8. enhancing local capabilities among Malaysian conservation professionals; and 9. raising the level of environmental awareness among stakeholders, general public and school children.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to estimate the abundance of orangutans in the Ulu Sungai Menyang landscape and to work with stakeholders to prepare a draft management plan of the area for the Sarawak Forest Department. The survey will be carried out on six plots in the landscape using the marked sign count method developed under a previous GACF grant. The project will consist of the following activities:..1. Identifying owners of native customary rights (NCR) lands and acquiring written permission to conduct orangutan nest count surveys in the Ulu Sungai Menyang landscape. ..2. Zoning the landscape for surveys, i.e. easily accessible and difficult-to-access areas. Six plots will be surveyed. Four of these are to be randomly selected from the easily accessible stratum and two from the more difficult to access stratum...3. Conducting five trips into the landscape within six months:.a. Trip 1. Will be for a reconnaissance (recce) survey to identify potential sites for setting the plots (to assess the accessibility of the areas), identify ideal guides for different sites, and to plan the travelling schedule for the training and three repeat surveys..b. Trip 2. Will be for the cutting of new strip lines for three plots..c. Trip 3 to 5. Will be for three repeat surveys at three different plots..d. Repeat Trips 1-5 for a second three plots...4. After the six months of surveys, compiling and analyzing the data. The data will then be used for the preparation of a final report on the orangutan population estimates at the Ulu Sungai Menyang landscape...5. In the final two months of the project period, initiating preparation of a management plan draft for the Ulu Sungai Menyang landscape. WCS Asia Program Madhu Rao will be brought in to facilitate the conceptual planning workshop..."

Identifying owners of native customary rights (NCR) lands and acquiring written permission to conduct orangutan nest count surveys in the Ulu Sungai Menyang landscape. ..2. Zoning the landscape for surveys, i.e. easily accessible and difficult-to-access areas. Six plots will be surveyed. Four of these are to be randomly selected from the easily accessible stratum and two from the more difficult to access stratum...3. Conducting five trips into the landscape within six months:.a. Trip 1. Will be for a reconnaissance (recce) survey to identify potential sites for setting the plots (to assess the accessibility of the areas), identify ideal guides for different sites, and to plan the travelling schedule for the training and three repeat surveys..b. Trip 2. Will be for the cutting of new strip lines for three plots..c. Trip 3 to 5. Will be for three repeat surveys at three different plots..d. Repeat Trips 1-5 for a second three plots...4. After the six months of surveys, compiling and analyzing the data. The data will then be used for the preparation of a final report on the orangutan population estimates at the Ulu Sungai Menyang landscape...5. In the final two months of the project period, initiating preparation of a management plan draft for the Ulu Sungai Menyang landscape. WCS Asia Program Madhu Rao will be brought in to facilitate the conceptual planning workshop..."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Postal Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring the tigers of the Endau-Rompin Landscape up to their full natural carrying capacity. This will be done by: a) continuing robust, on-the-ground law enforcement efforts in the designated permanent reserve forests within the ERL; b) carrying out surveillance for poachers and other intruders using camera-traps in this same area; c) conducting village briefings for local residents or communities in four districts of the ERL and d) identifying potential hotspots of human-tiger conflicts (HTC) along forest edges. Specifically, the applicant will: 1) carry out anti-poaching enforcement activities in the designated permanent reserve forests within the ERL including multiagency anti-poaching foot patrols, multi-agency anti-poaching vehicular patrols (4WD or motorbike) and mobile checkpoints, WCS-only foot and motorbike patrols, WCS-only anti-poaching surveillance camps and WCS-only undercover vehicular patrols, based on inputs from threat analyses, intelligence and reconnaissance trips; 2) conducting multimedia Messaging Service (MMS) camera-trapping at 20 sites in surveillance of poachers or intruders; 3) presenting at least six briefings to local communities in four districts within the ERL on the importance of wildlife and how to help prevent loss of wildlife and 4) carrying out a boundary survey along the ERL in order to identify potential hotspots of HTC and briefings at selected sites.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conservation of orangutans in the Batang Lemanak-Batang Skrang area of Lanjak-Entimau..Wildlife Sanctuary (LEWS) and in the Ulu Sungai Menyang area in Sarawak, Malaysia

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to increase the level of legal protection and rates of detection and reporting of illegal wildlife crimes in these lands through outreach and education to local people and by involving them in conservation activities. This will be done by: 1) conducting community dialogue and engagement prior to conducting the recce surveys; 2) conducting two recce surveys, to the Batang Lemanak and the Batang Skrang areas (both are in LEWS); 3) creating a spatial overlay of orangutan nest encounters for the landscape; 4) organizing meetings with Sarawak Forestry Corporation (SFC) and other potential partners to revise the current Conservation Outreach Program; 5) co-developing conservation oriented scripts with SFC for orangutan-themed skits based on the storyline of previously developed radio programs as a guideline; 6) supervising volunteers on prop preparation for the skits: 7) conducting orangutan- themed skits at seven longhouses in the landscape; 8) conducting a pilot test for the evaluation of the orangutan-themed skits at a resettled community in Sungai Rayu, Kuching; 9) conducting pre- and post-event evaluations for orangutan-themed skits to evaluate the impact of the event on the target audience; and 10) conducting two community dialogues to discuss the idea of setting up a Tagang Conservation System and joint community enforcement patrols to the designated zones.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Wildlife Conservation Society/Government of Malaysia supporting implementation of the National Elephant Conservation Action Plan for Peninsular Malaysia - Year 1

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to stimulate progress on the Government of Malaysias National Elephant Conservation Action Plan (NECAP), which has a 100-year vision to maintain wild Asian elephants in the seven Malaysia states where they are extant. Specific project activities will include: 1) review land-use and produce a land-use map within three Managed Elephant Ranges (MERs) listed in the NECAP using remote sensing imagery, ground-truthed data, revised MER boundaries, and landscape elements; 2) identify areas of MERs where elephants may be present and where land-use does not provide protection; and 3) work with and meet with Federal and State government agencies to inform them about the NECAP and MERs. This project aims to have the Government of Malaysia use their resources to implement the NECAP within ten years.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Wildlife Conservation Society/Government of Malaysia Peninsular Malaysia Elephant Project: Year 10, assessment and reduction of human-elephant conflict and capacity building in Endau-Rompin

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue human-elephant conflict (HEC) monitoring and mitigation work with villagers, patrolling of forest to protect elephants, gathering information through questionnaires to evaluate threat levels, and increase government capacity through collaboration on HEC incidents and provision of training on elephant management and HEC. Project activities will include: 1) continue community-based HEC assessment and mitigation work in five HEC-impacted Orang Asli villages and provide training in safe and effective methods for driving elephants from crops; 2) develop and implement a survey to assess HEC perception and mitigation uptake among farmers and threat severity to elephants in Orang Asli and Malay villages; 3) protect elephant populations and their habitat from poachers and encroachment by using the SMART patrol management system; and 4) increase engagement with government agencies to reduce the impact of elephants on agricultural productivity and reduce antagonism towards elephants in Johor. This project will help Malaysian authorities with developing and implementing a holistic elephant plan for Peninsular Malaysia to help balance development and conservation and improve the conservation wild Asian elephant populations in Malaysia.

title.narrative: Securing the long-term viability of the Kinabatangan Orang-utan population by reconnecting isolated forest fragments and supporting Honorary Wildlife Wardens' activities

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to finalize a Master Plan to reestablish a functional connectivity in Kinabatangan, and identify ways through policy gap analysis, recommendations for policy changes, compensation mechanisms and other incentives, that would allow for halting deforestation in the floodplain, and reinforce reforestation efforts undertaken by HUTAN-KOCP to restore the forest where natural regeneration cannot take place in order to enhance food supply and physical contiguity between isolated patches of forests. The project will also improve law enforcement by reinforcing capacities of the Honorary Wildlife Wardens to ensure that riparian and other protected forests are not encroached and degraded any further.

title.narrative: Citizen Action for Tigers: Engaging people to value and protect tigers and their habitats in Malaysia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to help people value and protect tigers and their habitats in Malaysia. Citizen Action for Tigers (CAT) involves citizen conservationists in protecting the western border of Taman Negara National Park and the Sungai Yu (Yu river) wildlife corridor. The corridor is the last forest linkage connecting the two largest tiger landscapes of 35,000 sq. km. in Malaysia. While hiking or camping in the forest, the volunteers deter poaching by their presence, destroy snares, support law enforcement by becoming additional eyes and ears, and document the presence of tigers and their prey by their signs and camera trap images. All relevant information is sent to MYCATs Wildlife Crime Hotline, which is subsequently relayed to the park authorities, and has resulted in the arrests of poachers and a trader. The project will support the following objectives: (1) Continue CAT at the Sungai Yu wildlife corridor, reducing threats and enabling wildlife recovery, maintaining the current level of protection and wildlife monitoring at the site using existing procedures, and (2) Expand CAT to a new site.

title.narrative: Conservation of the tigers of the Endau-Rompin Landscape, Malaysia, through on the ground law

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring the tigers of the greater Endau-Rompin Landscape up to their full natural carrying capacity. Project will continue robust, on the ground anti-poaching, law enforcement efforts in the Endau-Rompin Landscape (Johor and Pahang), by (a) Maintaining anti-poaching enforcement activities in Johor and Pahang including: multi-agency anti-poaching foot patrols, multi-agency anti-poaching vehicular patrols (4WD or motorbike) and mobile checkpoints, WCS-only foot patrols, and WCS-only vehicle patrols (motorbikes), based on inputs from threat analyses, intelligence and reconnaissance trips, (b) Swift Response Unit (SRU), and (c) Surveillance camera-trapping / access point monitoring for poachers in Johor and Pahang.

title.narrative: Combating the Illegal Wildlife Trade in Malaysia through conservation-relegion partnerships

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to reduce the severe threat of poaching and wildlife trafficking to tigers and priority species protected under the Wildlife Conservation Act 2010, in and around the Core Area of Taman Negara by addressing peoples attitudes towards nature. To date there has been no outreach to the predominantly Muslim communities living near the Core Area, although many poachers originate here. Specific activities include (1) empowering at.least 20 Muslim clerics in 24 villages (14,000 people) near the parks Core Area to spread awareness of the new state-wide wildlife trade fatwa; (2) reducing the involvement of these villagers in the wildlife trade and encourage them to report suspicious activities to authorities, through a shift in attitudes brought about by linking conservation with deeply held religious beliefs and values as enshrined in the fatwa; (3) reaching agreement with Muslim leaders to.issue a national level fatwa on illegal wildlife trade; and (4) disseminating best practices and lessons learnt on developing successful conservation-religious partnerships in priority wildlife trade hotspots."

title.narrative: Supporting SMART patrols in Project Harimau Selamanya to improve protection of the Malayan Tiger in the Kenyir-Taman Negara Core Area, Peninsular Malaysia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support largely indigenous patrollers to increase the number of Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) patrols to protect and increase tiger and prey populations in the Kenyir-Taman Negara Core Area. The project has the following objectives: (1) To secure current population of tigers in the Core Area. Activity 1.1: Deploy and retrieve camera traps at tiger hotspots; and (2) To eradicate poaching threats in the Core Area.

title.narrative: Scaling up the KOCP community-based Elephant Conservation Unit to better understand elephant ecology in man-made landscapes and mitigate raising conflicts with people.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to expand the range of an existing community-based Elephant Conservation Unit (ECU) to reach communities recently experiencing human-elephant conflict (HEC) as well as collect Asian elephant behavioral and socioecological data in agricultural landscapes in Sabah, Malaysia. Four additional members will be added to the ECU and their range will be increased to cover additional districts. Project activities include: 1) direct observations of Asian elephant herds within agricultural landscapes (especially oil palm), habitat assessments, and assessments of elephant-related damages; 2) identification and training of community members in HEC-affected villages; 3) surveys of local communities, and education and awareness events; 4) law enforcement patrols via an Honorary Wildlife Warden Program; and 5) contributing to the development of policy documents and strategies to manage Asian elephants and their ranges in Sabah. This project will contribute to the conservation of wild Asian elephant populations in Sabah by increasing knowledge of elephant ecology outside of protected areas, reducing HEC levels in areas with relatively new HEC activity, and contributing to efforts to better manage Sabahs wild elephants by informing policy and land-use decision-making by policymakers.

title.narrative: Assessing elephant habitat connectivity and usage in corridor sites in Pahang and Johor State in Peninsular Malaysia and reducing threats to the Asian elephant population in the Endau Rompin Landscape

description.narrative: This three-year project will work to maintain connectivity for Asian elephants across the Endau Rompin Landscape of peninsular Malaysia, and protect elephants through collaborative law enforcement and monitoring of habitat and landscape change. Project activities include: 1) mapping of plantation boundaries and fences to detect barriers to elephant movement; 2) assessing elephant use of pulpwood concessions; 3) landscape monitoring using Landsat 8 images; 4) SMART patrolling; 5) multi-stakeholder patrols; 6) deployment of motion-sensored cameras to monitor entry points into reserve forests; and 7) provision of basic conservation education programs for Orang Asli communities within the landscape. This project will contribute to the conservation of Asian elephants in Malaysia by reducing threats to elephants, protecting elephants from poaching syndicates, gaining a better understanding on elephant movement within a fragmented agroforestry landscape, better relationships with forest concession holders, and continuing dialogue with Orang Asli communities within the Endau Rompin Landscape of peninsular Malaysia. This award is provisionally approved for three phases or years funding, with each phase or year's funding dependent upon performance and financial management of the previous phase or year, meeting technical and financial reporting requirements, and availability of ASECF funds.

title.narrative: Peninsular Malaysias first Conservation K9 Unit to Combat Poaching and Illegal Wildlife Trade of Malayan Tiger and Rhinos

description.narrative: Malaysia is a source and transit country for internationally trafficked wildlife products. The Critically Endangered Malayan tiger (Panthera tigris jacksoni) is poached in Malaysia, and rhino horns are trafficked from Africa and Asia through Peninsular Malaysia to countries of demand. Conservation K9 units, the first of its kind in Peninsular Malaysia, composed of one tracking K9 unit to track poachers and snares in tiger habitats, and one detection K9 unit to detect wildlife contraband such as rhino horn and tiger parts at transit points, will increase the number of tiger snares extracted and poachers apprehended, and increase wildlife seizures. Once formed, these K9 units will be available for use to the Department of Wildlife and National Parks, Royal Malaysian Customs Department, global logistics and transport companies as well as local conservation NGOs. Project objectives are to enhance: (1) Effectiveness and efficiency of law enforcement efforts in wildlife trafficking points through the formation of a K9 detection unit; and, (2) Effectiveness and efficiency of law enforcement efforts in tiger habitats through the formation of a K9 tracking unit.

title.narrative: SUPPORTING SMART PATROLS TO IMPROVE PROTECTION OF THE MALAYAN TIGER IN THE KENYIR-TAMAN NEGARA CORE AREA, PENINSULAR MALAYSIA

description.narrative: Direct poaching of tigers and its principal prey, the Sambar (Rusa unicolor), are the main threats to the Malayan Tigers long-term survival and current trends throughout Peninsular Malaysia show that this threat is increasing. The goal of the Harimau Selamanya project in Rimba is to increase the population density of tigers in a Core Area that encompasses the Terengganu portion of Taman-Negara National Park, which is identified as Malaysias national priority area for tiger conservation and is one of the globally important Tiger Conservation areas. Specific objectives are to support Rimbas patrol team to: (1) Monitor tiger and prey populations in the Core Area, through annual camera trapping. Monitoring will help with better understanding tiger and prey population, and help evaluate the effectiveness of law enforcement interventions over time; and, (2) Eradicate poaching threats in tiger hotspots. Law Enforcement patrols will use Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART).

title.narrative: LIVING WITH ELEPHANTS - ESTABLISHING BETTER LANDSCAPE FOR HUMAN ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE IN MONOCULTURE HABITATS

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to ensure the long-term survival of wild Asian elephants in Kinabatangan, Malaysian Borneo by reducing human-elephant conflict and establishing elephant-friendly landscapes in the palm oil estates of Lower Kinabatangan. Project objectives are: 1) enhance scientific knowledge of elephant ecology and movement within palm oil landscapes; 2) develop and implement standard operating procedures (SOP) for the palm oil industry on coexistence with elephants; 3) build the capacity of young scientists and conservationists in Sabah in elephant ecology and conservation; and 4) revise the State Elephant Action Plan Elephant and related policy documents. Project activities include: 1) assess elephant feeding ecology and movement within palm oil landscapes to ascertain what resources are needed to support elephants outside of protected areas; 2) model elephant movement to identify the potential functional connectivity within the landscape; 3) engage and enhance communication with palm oil companies to develop SOPs and strategies to manage elephants in palm oil landscapes; and 5) develop the new State Elephant Action Plan. To make monoculture landscapes more elephant-friendly, scientific understanding of elephant ecology and behavior in these new man-made habitats is necessary and this project will contribute to this important effort.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING MALAYSIA S EFFECTIVENESS IN IMPLEMENTING AND ENFORCING CITES IN ORDER TO REDUCE ILLEGAL TRADE OF CITES-LISTED SPECIES

description.narrative: Malaysias strategic geographic location has resulted in the country becoming a major transit point for illegal wildlife trade destined for other markets in Asia. While Malaysia is the oldest Southeast Asia Party to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), challenges remain in obtaining timely information to combat the illegal trade and in navigating the divergent legal frameworks among the three Malaysian administrative jurisdictions (Peninsular Malaysia, and the Malaysian-Bornean states of Sabah and Sarawak). The purpose of this project is to counter the trafficking of CITES-listed wildlife in Malaysia by strengthening the countrys effectiveness in the implementation and enforcement of CITES. Specific activities of this two-year grant include: (1) a nationwide market survey market focused on traditional medicine outlets and pet shops in key locations in Malaysia and online to determine the scale of illegal trade and provide this information to relevant government agencies; (2) a review of wildlife legislation in Malaysia, focusing on Sabah and Sarawak, to identify gaps and make recommendations to ensure that wildlife laws are consistent across the country; and (3) strengthened engagement with regulatory bodies, traditional medicine and private-sector community to increase capacity to improve governance systems.

title.narrative: FOREST TO PLANTATIONS: ENSURE A FUTURE FOR ORANG-UTAN IN AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPES, KINABATANGAN, SABAH, MALAYSIAN BORNEO

description.narrative: The purpose of the project is to understand the orangutan dynamic in a landscape dominated by oil palm plantations, and promote peaceful co-existence between people and orangutans within an oil palm landscape. Project objects are to, (1) understand orangutan distribution within oil palm estates of Lower Kinabatangan, (2) understand the dynamic of orangutan sub-populations within an oil palm dominated landscape, (3) document the impact of habitat fragmentation of the residential status of female orangutans, (4) create a resilient landscape that will sustain orangutans in the long term, (5) assess crop damages due to orangutan presence, and, (6) ensure a peaceful acceptatance of orangutan presence within the oil palm plantations.

title.narrative: Developing a machine learning method to count orangutan nest in Malaysia and Indonesia on drone images to increase survey efficiency

description.narrative: (1) Data Collection/Labelling: Previously collected data will be utilized for training; (2) Model Training; (3) Testing and Validation: The 20,000 images used during training will be split into training/validation/test sets; (4) Web Deployment; (5) Ongoing network and classification model optimisation: The website will be used by the orangutan conservation community check the overall performance of the beta model while providing a feedback mechanism for any misclassifications, which will be used to interactively retrain the model once enough samples have been obtained; and, (6) Dissemination workshops: To disseminate the data analyses methods, the free website where people can upload orangutan nest images, and to provide recommendations about the best way to collect orangutan nest data with drones there will be two workshops..

title.narrative: LANDSCAPE APPROACH TO SAFEGUARD THE FUTURE OF BORNEAN ELEPHANT IN LOWER KINABATANGAN, SABAH BORNEO.

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to ensure the long-term survival of wild Asian elephants in Kinabatangan, Malaysian Borneo through implementation of the recommendations in the new Bornean Elephant Action Plan 2020-2029 (BEAP 2020-2029) and to continue building the capacity of young national conservation professionals. The activities proposed will support the implementation of three major objectives of the BEAP 2020-2029: (1) improve protection and reduce elephant deaths; (2) improve landscape connectivity and permeability; and (3) monitor and predict elephant population trends. This work, to be implemented at the landscape-level, is supported by the Kinabatangan-BEAP Taskforce, led by the Kinabatangan District Office and the local government, which coordinate all district level development activities. Project activities include: (1) improve the efficiency of the Honorary Wildlife Warden network; (2) undertake regular patrolling to monitor illegal activities; (3) develop and support eight local residents to serve as Community Elephant Ranger Teams in two villages; (4) train local communities and oil palm plantation workers on elephant behavior; (5) investigate the feasibility of a private insurance program; (6) produce a 5- minute Virtual Reality 360 video about human-elephant coexistence; (7) precise mapping and connectivity analysis of the location of elephant pathways; (8) investigate the possibility to create an integrated electric fencing policy at the district level; (9) re.survey the elephant population of Kinabatangan; and (10) build the capacity of two young scientists and conservationists in Sabah, Malaysia.

title.narrative: CITIZEN ACTION FOR TIGERS (CAT): ENGAGING PEOPLE TO VALUE AND PROTECT TIGERS AND THEIR HABITATS IN MALAYSIA - 3

description.narrative: This project aims to foster greater conservation stewardship through citizen actions with the following three-pronged approach:.Expanding wildlife and habitat protection through Community Ranger (CR) and Citizen Action for Tigers (CAT) Walk patrols,.which are foot patrols in tiger habitat, with added adaptive strategies; Increasing public involvement in tiger conservation through.CAT Walks; and Fostering an organic and active conservation focused community within CAT Walk alumni. The project has the.following objectives and activities: (1) Ensure tiger, wildlife and habitat are protected against any illegal activities surrounding the.Sungai Yu Corridor with (a) Targeted and coordinated patrols in key areas with supporting patrols in less accessible zones; (b).Conduct joint patrols, and outreach with the Department of Wildlife and National Parks (DWNP), Royal Malaysian Police (RMP),.and state Forest Department; (c) Operation of Wildlife Crime Hotline and coordination with the DWNP and RMP; and (2).Increased conservation stewardship and expansion of CAT Walks by (a) Expanding number of CAT Walks tapping into local.conservation networks, social media, wildlife enthusiast groups, and especially the eco-tourism market network both nationally,.regionally, and on a global scale; (b) Identifying, training, and mentoring new volunteer leaders for CAT Walks; (c) Identifying.new areas to expand CAT Walks into; and (d) Fostering conservation stewardship beyond CAT Walks.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF THE SOUTHERN RIVER TERRAPIN BATAGUR AFFINIS IN MALAYSIA THROUGH LOCAL COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION AND IMPROVED LAW ENFORCEMENT

description.narrative: This project aims to help conserve the remaining populations of this species in peninsular Malaysia. Wild.populations have been extirpated or depleted by consumption of eggs and meat and nesting habitat.destruction from sand mining throughout its remaining range in southern Thailand, Cambodia, and.peninsular Malaysia. Activities include: (1) collecting and relocating 800 wild river terrapin eggs to an.ex-situ hatchery to lower risks from predation and poaching; (2) head-starting 500 hatchlings for.reintroduction into the wild; (3) reducing illegal harvesting of eggs through community-based monitoring.programs along the Kemaman River; (4) working with local villagers to remove more than 500 kg of.discarded and illegal fishing gear in the Kemaman River; (5) compiling data on poaching and illegal trade.of this species into a document to present to key authorities to inform effective conservation.interventions; and (6) developing outreach and educational materials for target audiences on river terrapin.habitat, threats and protected status, as well as solutions needed for recovery.

title.narrative: ENFORCEMENT AND PROSECUTION: MAKING A CASE FOR THE MALAYAN TIGER

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to secure strong conviction outcomes for tigers and other wildlife crimes,.which will have a secondary effect of preventing the continued loss of the Malayan Tiger population..This will be achieved by working closely with the Department of Wildlife and National Parks Peninsular.Malaysia (DWNP) Legal and Enforcement teams (the key beneficiaries of capacity building), public.prosecutors and the Royal Malaysian Police to achieve the following three objectives: (1) By month 36, at.least 50% of the Enforcement Team targeted by the project show improvement in their knowledge and.proficiency to investigate crimes involving tigers and their prey; (2) By month 36, achieve at least 50% of.the prosecuted tiger and other totally protected wildlife cases tried by DWNP lead to a conviction; and (3).By month 36, at least 50% of convicted cases see penalties in accordance to the Wildlife Crime.Sentencing Guideline produced under the project.

title.narrative: TAKING STOCK: ESTABLISHING AN EFFECTIVE SAIGA HORN STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM IN MALAYSIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PREVENT ILLEGAL AND UNREGULATED TRADE OF SAIGA ANTELOPE HORN BY INSTITUTIONALIZING A TRANSPARENT AND ROBUST SAIGA HORN STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM IN A KEY CONSUMER COUNTRY MALAYSIA . SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES OF THIS THREE-YEAR GRANT INCLUDE 1 DEVELOPMENT OF A JOINT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND NATIONAL PARKS OF PENINSULAR MALAYSIA DWNP , 2 REVIEW OF PENINSULAR MALAYSIA S CURRENT SAIGA HORN STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND RESOURCES, 3 WORKSHOP TO ESTABLISH THE PROCESS FOR A SCOPING EXERCISE TO ASSESS TRADER-HELD SAIGA HORN STOCKPILES, 4 ASSESSMENT OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND QUANTITIES OF EXISTING SAIGA HORN STOCKPILES HELD BY TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE TCM TRADERS IN FOUR PENINSULAR MALAYSIA STATES AS WELL AS GOVERNMENT-HELD STOCKPILES, 5 REVIEW OF STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES IN CHINA, A KEY SAIGA HORN CONSUMER AND TRADING COUNTRY, INCLUDING INFORMATION SHARING MEETINGS BETWEEN RELEVANT GOVERNMENT AUTHORITIES IN CHINA AND MALAYSIA, 6 ESTABLISHMENT OF AN ELECTRONIC DATABASE FOR SAIGA STOCKPILES AND CLEAR STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES SOPS , 7 TRAINING FOR DWNP ON EFFECTIVE STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT, 8 DISSEMINATION OF PROJECT OUTCOMES AMONGST RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS, AND 9 SAIGA HORN TRADE MONITORING TO DETECT ILLEGAL PRACT

title.narrative: TAKING STOCK: ESTABLISHING AN EFFECTIVE SAIGA HORN STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM IN MALAYSIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PREVENT ILLEGAL AND UNREGULATED TRADE OF SAIGA ANTELOPE HORN BY INSTITUTIONALIZING A TRANSPARENT AND ROBUST SAIGA HORN STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM IN A KEY CONSUMER COUNTRY (MALAYSIA). SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES OF THIS THREE YEAR GRANT INCLUDE (1) DEVELOPMENT OF A JOINT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND NATIONAL PARKS OF PENINSULAR MALAYSIA (DWNP), (2) REVIEW OF PENINSULAR MALAYSIA S CURRENT SAIGA HORN STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND RESOURCES, (3) WORKSHOP TO ESTABLISH THE PROCESS FOR A SCOPING EXERCISE TO ASSESS TRADER HELD SAIGA HORN STOCKPILES, (4) ASSESSMENT OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND QUANTITIES OF EXISTING SAIGA HORN STOCKPILES HELD BY TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM) TRADERS IN FOUR PENINSULAR MALAYSIA STATES AS WELL AS GOVERNMENT HELD STOCKPILES, (5) REVIEW OF STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES IN CHINA, A KEY SAIGA HORN CONSUMER AND TRADING COUNTRY, INCLUDING INFORMATION SHARING MEETINGS BETWEEN RELEVANT GOVERNMENT AUTHORITIES IN CHINA AND MALAYSIA, (6) ESTABLISHMENT OF AN ELECTRONIC DATABASE FOR SAIGA STOCKPILES AND CLEAR STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPS), (7) TRAINING FOR DWNP ON EFFECTIVE STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT, (8) DISSEMINATION OF PROJECT OUTCOMES AMONGST RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS, AND (9) SAIGA HORN TRADE MONITORING TO DETECT ILLEGAL PRACT

title.narrative: FOREST TO PLANTATIONS: ENSURE A FUTURE FOR ORANG-UTAN IN AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPES, KINABATANGAN, SABAH, MALAYSIAN BORNEO

description.narrative: FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO UNDERSTAND THE ORANGUTAN DYNAMIC IN A LANDSCAPE DOMINATED BY OIL PALM PLANTATIONS, AND PROMOTE PEACEFUL CO EXISTENCE BETWEEN PEOPLE AND ORANGUTANS WITHIN AN OIL PALM LANDSCAPE. PROJECT OBJECTS ARE TO, (1) UNDERSTAND ORANGUTAN DISTRIBUTION WITHIN OIL PALM ESTATES OF LOWER KINABATANGAN, (2) UNDERSTAND THE DYNAMIC OF ORANGUTAN SUB POPULATIONS WITHIN AN OIL PALM DOMINATED LANDSCAPE, (3) DOCUMENT THE IMPACT OF HABITAT FRAGMENTATION OF THE RESIDENTIAL STATUS OF FEMALE ORANGUTANS, (4) CREATE A RESILIENT LANDSCAPE THAT WILL SUSTAIN ORANGUTANS IN THE LONG TERM, (5) ASSESS CROP DAMAGES DUE TO ORANGUTAN PRESENCE, AND, (6) ENSURE A PEACEFUL ACCEPTATANCE OF ORANGUTAN PRESENCE WITHIN THE OIL PALM PLANTATIONS.

title.narrative: IMPLEMENTING THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE LATEST ORANG-UTAN STATE ACTION PLAN IN LOWER KINABATANGAN

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO 1 EXPAND THE MONITORING OF ORANGUTANS IN FOREST PATCHES AND WITHIN OIL PALM PLANTATIONS DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AND ANALYZED ABOUT ORANGUTAN ECOLOGY IN AGRICULTURAL MOSAIC LANDSCAPES AND HOW THEY USE REFORESTED CORRIDORS NEW INNOVATIVE APPROACHES WILL BE DESIGNED WITH NEW TECHNOLOGY TO COLLECT INFORMATION ABOUT ORANGUTAN PRESENCE AND SURVIVAL IN AN OIL PALM LANDSCAPE, SUCH AS THE USE OF PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING TECHNIQUES AND EDNA 2 ENSURE MORE EFFECTIVE LAW ENFORCEMENT, FOR EXAMPLE ASSESSMENT OF ACTUAL CROP DAMAGE BY ORANGUTANS AND PROPOSE MITIGATION TECHNIQUES, WITHIN PLANTATIONS AND INCREASE AWARENESS OF ALL STAKEHOLDERS ABOUT THE PROTECTED AND ENDANGERED STATUS OF THE ORANGUTAN MINIMIZE THE LOSS OF ORANGUTANS WITHIN PLANTATION RAISE AWARENESS FOR PEACEFUL COEXISTENCE WITH ORANGUTANS AND 3 IDENTIFY AND CREATE FOREST CORRIDORS INSIDE OIL PALM PLANTATIONS TO INCREASE NATURAL FOREST COVER AND SUSTAIN ORANGUTAN SURVIVAL IN THIS LANDSCAPE CREATE AND MAINTAIN FOREST CORRIDORS FOR ORANGUTANS AND BIODIVERSITY.

title.narrative: LANDSCAPE APPROACH TO SAFEGUARD THE FUTURE OF BORNEAN ELEPHANT IN LOWER KINABATANGAN, SABAH, BORNEO, MALAYSIA

description.narrative: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE THE LONG-TERM SURVIVAL OF WILD ASIAN ELEPHANTS IN KINABATANGAN, MALAYSIAN BORNEO THROUGH IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE NEW BORNEAN ELEPHANT ACTION PLAN 2020-2029 BEAP 2020-2029 AND TO CONTINUE BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF YOUNG NATIONAL CONSERVATION PROFESSIONALS. THE ACTIVITIES PROPOSED WILL SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THREE MAJOR OBJECTIVES OF THE BEAP 2020-2029 1 IMPROVE PROTECTION AND REDUCE ELEPHANT DEATHS 2 IMPROVE LANDSCAPE CONNECTIVITY AND PERMEABILITY AND 3 MONITOR AND PREDICT ELEPHANT POPULATION TRENDS. THIS WORK, TO BE IMPLEMENTED AT THE LANDSCAPE-LEVEL, IS SUPPORTED BY THE KINABATANGAN-BEAP TASKFORCE, LED BY THE KINABATANGAN DISTRICT OFFICE AND THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT, WHICH COORDINATE ALL DISTRICT LEVEL DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 IMPROVE THE EFFICIENCY OF THE HONORARY WILDLIFE WARDEN NETWORK 2 UNDERTAKE REGULAR PATROLLING TO MONITOR ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES 3 DEVELOP AND SUPPORT EIGHT LOCAL RESIDENTS TO SERVE AS COMMUNITY ELEPHANT RANGER TEAMS IN TWO VILLAGES 4 TRAIN LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND OIL PALM PLANTATION WORKERS ON ELEPHANT BEHAVIOR 5 INVESTIGATE THE FEASIBILITY OF A PRIVATE INSURANCE PROGRAM 6 PRODUCE A 5- MINUTE VIRTUAL REALITY 360 VIDEO ABOUT HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE 7 PRECISE MAPPING AND CON
